'''The Man in the Moon Stayed Up Too Lat: ==History==
In ''[[The Prancing Pony]]'' at [[Bree]] [[Frodo Baggins
Hobbit]] poem composed by [[Bilbo Baggin: Frodo]] jumped on a table and recited "a ridiculous song" invented by [[Bilbo Baggins

'''The Man in the Moon Stayed Up Too Lat: ==Form==

The poem is in thirteen ballad-like five-line stanzas, introducing each element in turn: "the [[Man in the Moon]]" himself, the ostler's "tipsy cat that plays a five-stringed fiddle", the little dog, the "horn√©d cow".
==Portrayals in adaptations==
'''1978: [[The Lord of the Rings (1978 film)
:Frodo sings an abridged version of the song at the Prancing Pony before falling off the table and accidentally slipping on the [[The One Ring
Hobbit]] poem composed by [[Bilbo Baggin: Ring]] for the first time, causing him to disappear and startle the patrons.

'''The Man in the Moon Stayed Up Too Lat: '''1981: [[The Lord of the Rings (1981 radio series)
Hobbit]] poem composed by [[Bilbo Baggin: ''The Lord of the Rings'' (1981 radio series)]]:'''

'''The Man in the Moon Stayed Up Too Lat: :Frodo sings the song in Bree. Speeding up at every line, he becomes nigh unintelligible near the end.
'''2002: [[The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (video game)
Hobbit]] poem composed by [[Bilbo Baggin: ''The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring'' (video game)]]:'''

'''The Man in the Moon Stayed Up Too Lat: :Frodo sings an abridged version at the Prancing Pony. The line fragment ''"And there they brew a beer so brown"'' was changed to ''"And there they '''made''' a '''stew''' so brown"'', presumably to censor references to alcohol.
'''2012: ''[[The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey]]'':'''
:In the Extended Edition of the film, [[Bofur]] sings an abridged version in [[Rivendell]] while the [[Thorin and Company
Hobbit]] poem composed by [[Bilbo Baggin: Company]] dines with the [[Elves]], and the other [[Dwarves]] join in.

'''The Man in the Moon Stayed Up Too Lat: ===Other media===
A musical version of this poem was recorded by the [[Tolkien Ensemble]] on their album ''[[An Evening in Rivendell]]''.
==Inspiration==
In the context of the legendarium, this song is the imagined original (by back formation) ditty that is derived to 'our time' in the simplified nursery rhyme "Hey Diddle Diddle".{{fact}}
The title of this version is given in ''[[The Adventures of Tom Bombadil]]''.<ref>{{AB
